awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Principles and Techniques for Automated Middleware Specializations in Distributed Systems
awd_abstract_narration: Standardized general-purpose middleware remain an attractive option to develop performance-sensitive and safety-critical distributed systems due to their support for commonly required features that simplify distributed computing.  The feature-richness of these middleware and coarse-grained design, however, often adversely impact memory footprint and performance of the applications.  Proprietary solutions and handcrafted optimizations to standardized middleware are infeasible due to high development and maintenance costs.  This research is addressing these problems via automated specialization of general-purpose middleware (i.e., pruning unwanted features, and adding and customizing the necessary ones).  The intellectual merit of this research lies in how the automated specializations are realized by (a) identifying and exploiting the algebraic structure of middleware that helps map the specialization problem into a feature-oriented software development problem; (b) developing a new theory for feature composition, refactoring, and interactions across the lifecycle stages of applications; and (c) developing a well-defined specialization process based on generative programming.  The broader impact of this CAREER research is observed through the (a) development of new principles to design middleware that make them inherently amenable to specialization; (b) documentation of specialization patterns, which reduces software maintenance; (c) enhanced developer productivity and system correctness; and (d) transitioning of the research artifacts to education and scientific community through an open source tool suite called GAMMA (Generative Aspects for the Manipulation of Middleware Architectures).

por.por_cntn:
Software plays a key role in driving almost every aspect of our life these days. To promote rapid innovation, there is a need to reduce the efforts in reinventing the software capabilities. This has led to the design and development of middleware solutions. However, these middleware solutions have increasingly become too heavyweight leading to unnecessary performance overhead and extra consumption of resources, not to mention the difficulty in verifying the safety and trustworthy properties of the systems. To address these concerns while still preventing the need to reinvent, this CAREER research developed a variety of techniques that automate the fine tuning and configuration of general-purpose middleware so they can be utilized in various resource constrained communication environments to provide application quality of service including performance and fault tolerance.

A further dimension of the research focused on specialized algorithms and middleware for resource management in cloud infrastructures. A broader impact of these specializations stems from the beneficial environmental impact stemming from conservation of resources and energy needs in cloud data centers. 

All of these capabiities are all the more needed these days as the focus shifts broadly to paradigms such as Internet of Things and Cyber Physical Systems that aim to solve challenging societal needs such as Smart Cities. The insights and open source software and algorithms resulting from the CAREER research are enabling further research into Smart Cities and Advanced manufacturing. 

Insights from the CAREER research enabled the PI to develop new courses on Cloud Computing and Distributed Systems. He also supported multiple undergraduate students as summer research interns. The research also helped to build a STEM learning framework that uses real-world challenge problems for STEM learning. Finally, the CAREER research also paved the way to explore new research dimensions in Internet of Things by being an enabler for a small IoT testbed.
